contentheadline.headline: Church of God, House of Prayer

contentrichtext.text: The '''Church of God, House of Prayer''' is a [[Pentecostal]] [[Holiness movement|holiness]] body of [[Christianity|Christians]]. ==History== The '''Church of God, House of Prayer''', founded in 1939 by [[Harrison W. Poteat]] and incorporated in 1966, is doctrinally similar to the ''Church of God (Cleveland)''. They are [[Trinitarianism|Trinitarian]] and [[Arminian]] in theology, holding a [[millennium|premillennial]] view of eschatology. Other beliefs include the baptism of the [[Holy Ghost]], evidenced by [[glossolalia]]; water [[baptism]] by immersion; the [[The Lord's Supper|Lord's supper]] and [[feet washing]] for believers only; and that the atonement provides not only for spiritual rebirth, but also for healing and deliverance from evil spirits. ==Organization== In 1979, the '''Church of God, House of Prayer''' had 24 churches in the eastern [[United States]], and 2 churches in eastern [[Canada]]. {{citation needed|date=October 2007}} The estimated membership was 1200. {{citation needed|date=October 2007}} Local congregations are "integral parts" of the General Assembly of the '''Church of God, House of Prayer''', and are subject to the General Assembly and its officials. Headquarters are in [[Markleysburg, Pennsylvania]]. ==Further reading== *''Encyclopedia of American Religions'', J. Gordon Melton, editor *''Profiles in Belief: the Religious Bodies of the United States and Canada'', by Arthur Carl Piepkorn ==External links== *[http://www.adherents.com/Na/Na_185.html#1045 Adherents.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:Church Of God, House Of Prayer}} [[Category:Pentecostal denominations]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1939]] [[Category:Christian denominations, unions, and movements established in the 20th century]] [[Category:1939 establishments in the United States]] {{Christian-denomination-stub}}
